conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to consider the forces acting on the balls and the equilibrium of the system.

The inner wall and the mouth of the smooth hemispherical bowl are fixed on the horizontal surface, and the mouth of the bowl remains level. A ball, C ball, and B ball are connected by two thin light wires. θ = 30°.
The ball A is hanging on the left side of the bowl, ball B is inside the bowl, and ball C is hanging on the right side of the bowl.
The system remains at rest, so the net force acting on each ball must be zero.
The ball B has just no pressure on the bowl wall, so the forces acting on ball B are only due to the wires and gravity.
The net force acting on ball C must be equal to the net force acting on ball B for the system to remain in equilibrium.
The tension in the wire connecting ball A to ball B must balance the weight of ball A.
The tension in the wire connecting ball C to ball B must balance the weight of ball C.
The angle θ = 30° affects the direction of the tension forces in the wires.
Using trigonometric relationships, the horizontal and vertical components of the tension forces can be analyzed to find the mass ratio of ball A to ball C.
